utterances: Earlier this week in Des Moines, I wandered into a T-shirt shop called SMASH in a hip part of town known as the East Village.
Twenty-four-year-old Mike Draper of Van Meter, Iowa, owns the store.
And lately, he told me, they've been doing a brisk business in politically themed shirts.
The first one we came up with was Iowa 2008 Rock Out With Your Caucus Out.
And the second one is Iowa Our Caucus is Bigger, Better, and Comes Before New Hampshire.
I'm not sure that's NPR appropriate.
When it comes to his own political views, Mike is actually quite serious.
He's gone to campaign events.
He's hung out with staffers.
And recently he's decided to back Barack Obama.
His friend and business partner, Garrett Cornilson(ph), who grew up in St. Charles, Iowa, will do the same.
When I listen to politicians, it's hard to decipher what's real and what's not and when they're acting, but I get the best sense of - from Obama that what he's saying is genuine.
Mike says he likes Senator Obama's fresh approach.
He sees it as a stark contrast to Hillary Clinton.
I kind of worry about the logic of thinking that things were good under the Clinton years, so if you bring all those people back, that things are going to be just as good again.

You know, it's kind of like, if you used to have a good high school football team and four years later you try to bring all those guys back again to play, it's not really going to be like the same game.
Like many 20-somethings, neither Mike nor Garrett own landline phones.
So they say they miss out on a lot of the campaign calls most other Iowa households receive.
They also don't own TVs.
So last night they met up with about a dozen friends at Frank's Pizza to watch the Democratic candidates debate.
(Soundbite of debate)
Some believe you get change by demanding it.
Some believe you get it by hoping for it.
I believe...
Unidentified Man #1: Ouch.
The group reacts throughout the evening.
At times it almost feels as if they're watching a football game.
There's plenty of smack talk.
And even though there are several Hillary Clinton fans in the mix, Mike holds nothing back.
And especially when the senator answered what she'd do her first year in office if elected.
And I would be even more passive-aggressive than I am now.
Often the talk on TV gets drowned out by the group drinking Miller beer and eating pesto pizza.
They debated amongst themselves about topics like taxes, education and health care.
Unidentified Man #2: I don't have health care, and I refuse to pay for it.
I don't want to spend that many hours in my week paying for (unintelligible) if they could reduce costs right off the bat and say, like, stop doing such extensive background checks on people...
But the group was all ears and rolling eyes whenever a candidate mentioned or thanked Iowa.
I asked Mike if it ever get tiresome, candidates trying to garner street cred by saying how great Iowa is.
Yeah, you don't have to pander.
Like we recognize it.
It's like the rock bands who says you guys are the greatest crowd we've had yet.
I love you, Davenport.
This is Des Moines.
Des Moines.
At the end, Mike says the debate did nothing but reaffirm his gut feeling that Obama was the clear and only choice.
He could be the JFK for our generation, he told me.
Mike's friend and business partner, Garrett Cornilson, agreed, but with a bit less optimism.
He said he's troubled by all the promises the candidates made.

You know, this is easy to say it now, but like in a year, when you're actually in office, are any of these things going to actually, like, come to fruition and, like, are we really - are any of these goals and plans and lofty ambitions, like, are they going to be realized?
If any one candidate could really convince young voters that their campaign promises would be fulfilled, that would win the vote, at least of this group, in a heartbeat.
Alex Cohen, NPR News, Des Moines.
From NPR News, this is DAY TO DAY.
In Texas, a big media company is selling off its newspaper holdings to concentrate on its TV business.
The company is called Belo.
John Dimsdale is here now from MARKETPLACE.
And John, tell us more about Belo and why it's doing this.
Matt, one of the founding members of Arts and Crafts, Dennis Irwin, he died back in 2008, and there's a track on this record that's played by your trumpeter...
Terell Stafford.
Yeah...
And its human nature for people to always expect their house is worth what it was at the top of the market, which most economists would agree was last July.
Now what about buyers?
We assume that it's a better time for buyers, but is it?
You know, it is a better time for buyers because there's a lot of more inventory.
I would say if I was a buyer right now I would definitely take my time.
You don't have to panic now, you can put that home inspection contingency, you can start to ask for concessions; perhaps seller financing.
You've got some flexibility on move-in dates.
If you're a buyer, don't you have to worry about interest rates, though?
You do have to worry about interest rates.
I would suggest that you start talking to lenders now and try to get an extended lock rate on mortgage interest rates.
They are going up.
An extended lock rate?
That means for how long can you get it that you can...?
Well that's negotiable.
Try to get as long a lock as you can; 30 days, 90 days, whatever you can negotiate.
Then go out shopping and make sure that it's really the home that you want.
The other really important thing I think everyone should keep in mind is no longer should you be looking at your house like an ATM machine.
It's a house.
It's not an investment; its shelter.
And if you do that, you'll find a house that really is your dream house, not just what you think somebody else is going to buy later on.
And I think everybody will be better off when that happens.
Well June Fletcher, it's good to lock in on your advice.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
June Fletcher is the author of House Poor: Pumped Up Prices, Rising Rates, and Mortgages on Steroids, How to Survive the Coming Housing Crisis.
June, are you still there?
Yes, I'm still here.
Is there still a housing crisis coming?
You know, it could very well be for the markets that have been overvalued, like Los Angeles, Los Vegas, where it's all been pumped up.
You know, typically the higher they've gone, the harder they fall when they do fall.
Depends on where you are.
It really does.
Well June, thanks again.
All right.
Nice talking with you.
Iraq's government is enforcing a curfew today in Baghdad.
That is significant because Friday is the Muslim day of prayer.
People are being told to stay home to prevent any more sectarian attacks.
Nearly 200 people, many of them Sunni Muslims, have died in the violent reprisals that followed Wednesday's bombing of a major Shiite Muslim shrine.
This morning we've called a Sunni leader.
Saleh Mutlag is head of the National Dialogue Council, and he joins us once again from Baghdad.
Welcome to the program again.
Thank you very much.
Sir, people have been raising the possibility of an all out civil war in Iraq following this mosque attack and the reprisals for it.
Are you concerned about a civil war?
Well, I'm concerned and everybody in Iraq is very concerned about it, a civil war maybe at the beginning.
But actually what's happening now is not a real civil war.
It is a war between some sectarian parties from the Shia.
Again it's (unintelligible).
